Item 1. Business.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 1. Business section of AAPL's Form 10-K in bullet points:

• The Company designs, manufactures and markets smartphones, personal computers, tablets, wearables and accessories, and sells a variety of related services.
• The fiscal year ends on the last Saturday of September, typically a 52- or 53-week period.
• The iPhone line includes iPhone 16 Pro, iPhone 16, iPhone 15, iPhone 14, and iPhone SE.
• The Mac line includes laptops MacBook Air, MacBook Pro, desktops iMac, Mac mini, Mac Studio, and Mac Pro.
• The iPad line includes iPad Pro, iPad Air, iPad, and iPad mini.
• Apple Watch Ultra 2, Apple Watch Series 10, and Apple Watch SE are part of the Company's line of smartwatches based on watchOS operating system.
• The Company offers a portfolio of fee-based service and support products under the AppleCare brand.
• The Company operates various platforms, including the App Store, that allow customers to discover and download applications and digital content.
• Apple Arcade, Apple Fitness+, Apple Music, Apple News+, and Apple TV+ are subscription-based services offered by the Company.

Item 1A. Risk Factors.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Item 1A. Risk Factors section of Apple Inc.'s 2024 Form 10-K in bullet points:

• The Company's business, reputation, results of operations, financial condition, and stock price can be affected by various factors, including those described below.

• Adverse macroeconomic conditions, such as slow growth or recession, high unemployment, inflation, tighter credit, higher interest rates, and currency fluctuations, can adversely impact consumer confidence and spending.

• The Company's international operations represent a majority of its total net sales, and the global supply chain is large and complex.

• Uncertainty about or a decline in global or regional economic conditions can have a significant impact on suppliers, contract manufacturers, logistics providers, distributors, cellular network carriers, and other channel partners.

• Adverse economic conditions can lead to increased credit and collectibility risk on the Company's trade receivables; the failure of derivative counterparties and other financial institutions; limitations on the Company's ability to issue new debt; reduced liquidity; and declines in the fair values of the Company's financial instruments.

• Political events, trade and other international disputes, geopolitical tensions, conflict, terrorism, natural disasters, public health issues, industrial accidents, and other business interruptions can have a material adverse effect on the Company and its customers, employees, suppliers, contract manufacturers, logistics providers, distributors, cellular network carriers, and other channel partners.

• The Company's past financial performance should not be considered a reliable indicator of future performance.

Item 1C. Cybersecurity.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 1C. Cybersecurity section in bullet points:

• The Company's Head of Corporate Information Security has over 25 years of experience in the cybersecurity industry.
• The Head of Corporate Information Security leads a dedicated Information Security team since 2016.
• The Company engages third parties to assess, test, or assist with aspects of its security processes and incident response as needed.
• A dedicated Supplier Trust team manages information security risks related to supplier relationships.
• The Company has processes in place to log, track, address, and escalate cybersecurity incidents across the Company and its suppliers.
• The Audit Committee regularly reviews and discusses the Company's cybersecurity risks with management, including the Head of Corporate Information Security.

Item 2. Properties.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 2. Properties section as bullet points:

• The company's headquarters is located in Cupertino, California.
• As of September 28, 2024, the company owned or leased facilities and land for corporate functions, R&D, data centers, retail, and other purposes at locations throughout the U.S. and outside the U.S.
• The company believes its existing facilities and equipment are in good operating condition and suitable for business conduct.

Item 3. Legal Proceedings.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - Item 3. Legal Proceedings section:

• On March 25, 2024, the Commission announced two formal noncompliance investigations against AAPL under the Digital Markets Act (DMA).
• The Commission's investigations concern Article 5(4) of the DMA and Article 6(3) of the DMA.
• On June 24, 2024, the Commission announced preliminary findings in the Article 5(4) investigation, alleging that AAPL's App Store rules are in breach of the DMA.
• The Commission has opened a third formal investigation against AAPL regarding its new contractual requirements for third-party app developers and app marketplaces.
• If the Commission makes a final determination of violation, it can issue a cease and desist order and impose fines up to 10% of AAPL's annual worldwide net sales.
• On March 21, 2024, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) filed a civil antitrust lawsuit against AAPL in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey.
• The DOJ is seeking equitable relief to redress alleged anticompetitive behavior.
• Various civil litigation matters have been filed in state and federal courts in the U.S., alleging similar violations of U.S. antitrust laws.
• Epic Games, Inc. filed a lawsuit against AAPL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, alleging violations of federal and state antitrust laws and California's unfair competition law.
• The California District Court found that certain provisions of AAPL's App Store Review Guidelines violate California's unfair competition law and issued an injunction.
• On January 16, 2024, AAPL implemented a plan to comply with the injunction.

Item 5. Market for Registrant’s Common E.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 5. Market for Registrant’s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities in bullet points:

• As of October 18, 2024, there were 23,301 shareholders of record.
• The Company was authorized to purchase up to $110 billion of its common stock under a share repurchase program announced on May 2, 2024.
• As of September 28, 2024, $20.9 billion had been utilized from the $110 billion share repurchase program.
• During the fourth quarter of 2024, the Company utilized the final $4.1 billion under its previous repurchase program authorized in May 2023.
• The share repurchase programs do not obligate the Company to acquire a minimum amount of shares and may be repurchased in privately negotiated or open market transactions.

Item 7. Management’s Discussion and Anal.summary:
Here are the key facts from the Management's Discussion and Analysis section in bullet points:

• The Company announced new product, service, and software offerings in 2024, including MacBook Pro 14-in., MacBook Pro 16-in., iMac, iPad Air, iPad Pro, iOS 18, macOS Sequoia, iPadOS 18, watchOS 11, visionOS 2, tvOS 18, Apple Intelligence, iPhone 16, iPhone 16 Plus, iPhone 16 Pro, and iPhone 16 Pro Max.

• The Company's fiscal year is the 52- or 53-week period that ends on the last Saturday of September, with an additional week included in the first fiscal quarter every five or six years.

• Macroeconomic conditions, including inflation, interest rates, and currency fluctuations, have impacted the Company's results of operations and financial condition.

• Americas net sales increased during 2024 compared to 2023 due primarily to higher net sales of Services.
• Europe net sales increased during 2024 compared to 2023 due primarily to higher net sales of Services and iPhone.
• Greater China net sales decreased during 2024 compared to 2023 due primarily to lower net sales of iPhone and iPad.
• Japan net sales increased during 2024 compared to 2023 due primarily to higher net sales of iPhone.
• Rest of Asia Pacific net sales increased during 2024 compared to 2023 due primarily to higher net sales of Services.

• iPhone net sales were relatively flat during 2024 compared to 2023.
• Mac net sales increased during 2024 compared to 2023 due primarily to higher net sales of laptops.
• iPad net sales decreased during 2024 compared to 2023 due primarily to lower net sales of iPad Pro and the entry-level iPad models, partially offset by higher net sales of iPad Air.
• Wearables, Home and Accessories net sales decreased during 2024 compared to 2023

Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Di.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk, formatted as bullet points:

• As of September 28, 2024, the Company estimates a maximum one-day loss in fair value of $538 million for its foreign currency derivative positions due to adverse movements in exchange rates.
• As of September 30, 2023, the Company estimates a maximum one-day loss in fair value of $669 million for its foreign currency derivative positions due to adverse movements in exchange rates.
• The Company's exposure to interest rate risk primarily affects its investment portfolio and term debt, with increases in U.S. interest rates negatively affecting the fair value of these assets and liabilities.
• To protect against interest rate risk, the Company may use derivative instruments, offset interest rate-sensitive assets and liabilities, or control duration of the investment and term debt portfolios.
• The Company's exposure to foreign exchange rate risk primarily affects its net sales and gross margins as expressed in U.S. dollars, with changes in exchange rates negatively affecting these metrics.

Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplem.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data section in bullet points:

• The fiscal year of Apple Inc. ends on the last Saturday of September, with an additional week included every five or six years to realign fiscal quarters with calendar quarters.
• Revenue is recorded net of taxes collected from customers that are remitted to governmental authorities.
• Share-based compensation expense is recognized on a straight-line basis for its estimate of equity awards that will ultimately vest.
• Cash equivalents are treated as cash and have maturities of three months or less at the date of purchase.
• Marketable securities are valued using the specific identification method.
• Inventories are measured using the first-in, first-out method.
• Depreciation on property, plant and equipment is recognized on a straight-line basis.
• Derivative instruments are presented at their gross fair values in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.
• The Company records certain deferred tax assets and liabilities in connection with the minimum tax on certain foreign earnings created by the TCJA.

Item 9A. Controls and Procedures.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 9A. Controls and Procedures section of AAPL's 2024 Form 10-K, formatted as bullet points:

• As of September 28, 2024, the Company's principal executive officer and principal financial officer concluded that the Company's disclosure controls and procedures were effective in providing reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed by the Company was recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within specified time periods.

• The Company's internal control over financial reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with GAAP.

• The Company's internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures related to:
  • Maintenance of accurate records
  • Recording of transactions
  • Authorization of receipts and expenditures

• Management does not expect that the Company's internal controls will prevent or detect all errors and all fraud, but rather provide reasonable assurance against material misstatement.

• The Company's management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting, which was effective as of September 28, 2024, based on an assessment using the 2013 framework from the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.

Item 9B. Other Information.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - Item 9B. Other Information as bullet points:

• Deirdre O'Brien entered into a trading plan on August 27, 2024, to satisfy Rule 10b5-1(c) conditions.
• The plan allows for the sale of shares vesting between April 1, 2025 and October 1, 2026, excluding withheld shares due to tax obligations.
• Deirdre O'Brien's plan will expire on December 31, 2026, subject to early termination.
• Jeff Williams entered into a trading plan on August 29, 2024, to satisfy Rule 10b5-1(c) conditions.
• The plan allows for the sale of up to 100,000 shares and shares vesting between April 1, 2025 and October 1, 2025.
• Jeff Williams' plan will expire on December 15, 2025, subject to early termination.

Item 10. Directors, Executive Officers a.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - Item 10. Directors, Executive Officers and Corporate Governance section in bullet points:

• The Company has an insider trading policy governing the purchase, sale, and other dispositions of its securities.
• The policy applies to all Company personnel, including directors, officers, employees, and other covered persons.
• A copy of the Company's insider trading policy is filed as Exhibit 19.1 to this Form 10-K.
• The remaining information required by this Item will be included in the Company's definitive proxy statement to be filed with the SEC within 120 days after September 28, 2024.

Item 15. Exhibit and Financial Statement.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART IV - Item 15. Exhibit and Financial Statement Schedules section:

• All financial statements were filed as part of this report.
• The required financial statement schedules have been omitted due to insufficient information or inclusion in consolidated financial statements.
• Exhibits required by Item 601 of Regulation S-K include Apple Inc.'s 2024 Form 10-K, items 53, 54, and 55.
• Certain instruments defining long-term debt securities are omitted, but the company undertakes to furnish them upon request.

Item 16. Form 10-K Summary.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART IV - Item 16. Form 10-K Summary section:

• Apple Inc.'s 2024 Form 10-K report has been signed by the company.
• The report was signed on behalf of the Registrant by the following persons: 
    (list of signers is not provided in the given text)
• Timothy D. Cook and Luca Maestri are authorized to sign amendments to the Annual Report on Form 10-K.
• Apple Inc.'s attorneys-in-fact have the power of substitution for signing amendments to the report.
